lexUnit.name: sister-in-law.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the sister of one's wife or husband, or the wife of one's brother or brother-in-law.

sentence.text: There were also two of Antonietta 's brothers , a brother and sister-in-law of Gennaro 's and one of Gennaro 's uncles .
He married first Margaret Edwin , secondly Mary Cox , widow and sister-in-law of a politically moderate parliamentarian colonel .
This was the period of her last obsessive attachment , to Vý Oumanýf , sister-in-law of the philosopher Jacques Maritain .
She used to spend her whole day locked in a basement room with her sister-in-law and the four young children they had between them .
Unfortunately he shared with his sister-in-law an inability to wear clothes so it looked like a bloody awful Australian suit .
It was true that Penelope was a vicar 's sister-in-law , but that was a poorer , meaner thing altogether .
The second marriage united Judith 's brother Conrad with Adelaide , who was Lothar 's sister-in-law .
I tried to get the book for my sister-in-law for her birthday but most places were sold out .
For tonight at least , she was Anne Mowbray , sister-in-law to the handsome prince who was soon to be crowned .
He had aunts in Bombay and brothers in Edinburgh , cousins in North Africa and sisters-in-law in Australia .

“ I gave away a Moses basket to my sister-in-law without realising he had planked £1,000 under the mattress .
